holidays.name: National Cookie Exchange Day
holidays.description: A perfect day to gather friends or family to swap your favorite homemade cookies. It’s a sweet way to share recipes and fill your holiday season with delicious treats!
holidays.origin: Originated as a fun tradition among holiday baking enthusiasts in the United States to spread cookie joy during the festive season.
holidays.funFact: Some cookie exchangers create themed packages, like ‘Around the World’ cookies representing different cultures!

holidays.name: Forefathers’ Day
holidays.description: Commemorates the landing of the Pilgrims at Plymouth Rock in 1620, honoring their courage and perseverance.
holidays.origin: Observed primarily in Plymouth, Massachusetts, this day highlights the legacy of the early settlers who helped shape American history.
holidays.funFact: Forefathers’ Day is one of the oldest commemorative celebrations in the U.S., dating back to the 18th century.

holidays.name: National Haiku Poetry Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the art of haiku, the traditional Japanese form of poetry consisting of three lines and 17 syllables.
holidays.origin: Inspired by the beauty and brevity of haiku as a poetic form, this day encourages creativity and mindful observation of nature.
holidays.funFact: Many people write haikus about winter's quiet beauty on this day, capturing frosty mornings in just a few words.

holidays.name: Look on the Bright Side Day
holidays.description: An uplifting observance encouraging people to find the silver lining in any situation—perfect for beating the winter blues.
holidays.origin: A modern feel-good day that promotes optimism and positive thinking, regardless of circumstances.
holidays.funFact: Even on the shortest days of the year, this holiday reminds us that every cloud has a silver lining!
